The Goldwaterites of the 1960s took over the Republican Party. But the McGovernites (the New Left) of the 1960s took over the Democratis. They were nearly as anti-government as the Republicans. They were the big de-regulators, and then Obama simply reappointed the failed Bob Rubin team who are following the same low tax policy (three points on the top 2%!!!), fake regulation (read Sheila Bair's Down in the Dumps), and doctrinnaire free trade. Indeed, the Rubin crew is following a QE3-zero interest policy to force investors to take new risks with their retirement in a bond and maybe stock bubble.

The Republicans are moving rapidly to the left to appeal to their New Deal base A team of, say, Jeb Bush and Sheila Bair as VP, would wipe out Hillary from 25 years in the past and the Rubin team. At least the Republicans know they have to move to the center. New Democrats like Krugman have no suspicion that they must abandon the 1960s as well and what faces them. They just keep appealing to the wealthy suburbs as their "left-wing base" and Obama is quite likely going for European austerity.

Also:
Cut 1/3 of military budget
Stop the drug war
Cap deductions to $25k
Tax all capital gains as ordinary income
Make the top marginal rate 39%
And we're there
Rob P
http://cfdemsblog.com
Good work..that is basically the same list I announced a couple of weeks ago in my weekly radio commentary on our local community radio station.  However, I raised the cap on payroll tax to $500,000

Eliminate the mortgage interest deduction on the third, fourth, fifth, etc. homes people own.  Keep the deduction for the family's main home and one other, but if you own more than two homes--you can afford to pay the interest on those mortgages.

Here are a few spending cuts and sources of revenue off the top of my head:

1. Eliminate Cold-War-inspired weapons systems development from the military budget.

2. Close 1/4 of the US military bases on foreign soil.

3. Eliminate subsidies to oil companies, which are the most profitable businesses in history.

4. Define family farms in terms that prevent giant agribusiness corporations from receiving subsidies and taking deductions that are intended for what the average taxpayer envisions as a family farm.

5. Negotiate drug prices with big pharma for Medicare, which is how drug prices are set now for Medicaid.

6. Charge a 0.02% transaction tax on sales of stock held for less than one day.

7. End the carried interest loophole.

8. Tax capital gains over $1,000,000 as ordinary income, which it is.

9. Excluding capital investments and spending on R&D, prevent corporations from paying less than half of their tax bill before deductions.

10. Raise the cap on payroll tax income to $200,000 or eliminate it entirely.

There must be hundreds more.

I admit that half of my suggestions are tax hikes, but I am a balanced kind of guy.

The third rail of Republican policy has been to unleash senseless wars and promote fear, resulting in accrued military costs, which constitute a good part of the debt, as well as annual deficits.   Just as support for the unfunded Viet Nam conflict [together with support from Southern Democrats] effectively de-funded Johnson's War on Poverty, so to the unfunded Iraq II and Afghanistan conflicts added leverage to those who would attempt to destroy the vestiges of the Welfare State.

This wounded beast is nevertheless doing a great deal of harm as it angrily flails about.  It is far from dead.  The anti-union moves made in Wisconsin and Detroit are realizing a right wing dream that goes back decades.  These elected officials have been chosen by our fellow Americans.  One can only assume that among those who have voted in right wing politicians there are more than a few members of the working class.  One could argue that it is not the Republican Party that is in trouble, it is the Democratic Party.  And the party's problem is that it is losing ground not merely with the white middle class but with its traditional base, the white working class.  Fewer and fewer belong to unions.  Many are angry with their brethren in public service unions, one of the last bastions of unionism in the country.  Unless the Democratic Party takes steps--and soon--to assure its erstwhile adherents that it is on their side, we will see a continuing downward spiral into the kind of political know-nothingism and frustration that is the traditional soil in which fascism grows.  A voting coalition of the poor and academics is not large enough to put decent men and women into our legislative bodies.

Good points.

And the Dems on the national and state level should immediately mobilize a major campaign to neutralize gerrymandering the way California just did -- through popular referenda. Nowadays, a neutral panel of judges, not the legislature or governor -- draws up California's electoral districts.

It already is very, very ugly. Republicans control thirty of fifty Statehouses, and one or more chambers in many state legislatures. They are using their power in those states to gerrymander a long-term control of their legislatures and their delegation to Congress, they are attacking organized labor and other liberal coalitions, they are delaying or hampering the implementation of federal programs, and they are using their positions to "bully pulpit" their message.

If Democrats cannot win back some of those states then they will continue to have a divided Congress and state resistance to their programs. Both the Republican and the Democratic Party have had their obituaries read in the past, but both still are here. We must be careful not to gloat over thwarting Republican Plan A only to be beaten by Republican Plan B!

The only practical thing to do now is keep the status quo. No tax increases and no cuts in government spending. The Dow Jones Index doubled since March of 2009 and unemployment is headed down. Why rock the boat now?

To avoid the charge of a calculated farce, one might look at some real reform such (1) making hedge fund managers pay the same rates as everybody else, (2) making all corporation based here, de facto or de jure, pay tax on all their income, subject to dollar for dollar credit for foreign taxes paid (3) Have anyone who has earned income of over a million pay 3% surcharge for Social Security (4) Go back and get the alleged $60+ billion in Medicare fraud.

That's not really true. Many of the new malls are out towards Whitefield, and one of the nicest and newest, Orion Mall at Brigade Gateway, is basically built as part of a new suburb with a hotel, restaurants, offices, condos and even its own hospital-- and it's all out on the far western side of town.

The only people obsessed with colonial pasts and defining India through a colonial prism seem to be the US media. Note the breathless coverage about that unemployed couple of Will and Kate. Colonialism is mostly a fading memory in India which doesn't evoke very strong feelings these days. As the article hints there is little support for re-doing Lutyen's Delhi. But in a country of over a billion people if you want to find a minority with any contrarian view to support a pre-conceived view you can always find ready quotes. Don't let that stop you from advertising your biases and condemning whole countries and cultures and psychoanalyzing their "self esteem". "Old Delhi" is only as haphazard as any other cities of that vintage. You know the kind of places in Europe that most Americans rhapsodize about because it is "so historic". The problem isn't the architecture. But like many other places in India it could do with a good scrubbing.

Old Delhi is not ugly - it is more lively and feels more real than New Delhi. Lutyens Delhi was built to signal the aloofness and power of the ruling class and it shows. Agree with the rest of your comment.

@AdamS No need to take a dig at Pakistan. Pakistan has done a pretty good job of preserving its historical sites, which include the neolithic site of Mehrgarh (7000 BC), the Indus Valley sites of Mohenjo-daro and Harappa (3300-2200 BC), and the Buddhist sites of Taxila (500 BC to 100 AD) and Takht-i-Bahi (100 AD). There is nothing like these sites in India, both in provenance and abundance of artifacts.

Also, Pakistan has allowed the best international archaeologists to work at these sites, which ensures that they receive state of the art attention. India, on the other hand, has not. The Archaeological Survey of India, which until the 1960s had some excellent archaeologists and epigraphists, is now a second-rate institution.

Has anyone noticed the mostly unattractive and shabby buildings designed by the current core of Indian architects, who need lessons in engineering as well as aesthetics! (India woefully lacks trained civil engineers and architects.). Should India preserve its unique history and the legacy of all the "colonialists" who contributed to it? But of course! Luytens Delhi still looks more modern and stylish than the haphazard ugly "old" Delhi. The impulse to re-do reveals low self-esteem of most Indians. Should you destroy or remake all the monuments and buldings (e.g. Taj Mahal, Red Fort) becuase they represent the legacy of "colonialists" who preceded the British? One should be proud of India's multi-religious, multi-ethnic civilization, one of the oldest and richest in the world. Pakistan next door is a cuationary tale of a manufactured ideology hell-bent on destroying its pre-Islamic and glorious past.

I for one would not like to make any changes. Every city from Bangalore to Mumbai or Chennai and Calcutta have deteriorated in beauty and quality of life by cramming high rises and eliminating low density houses. The problem has been lack of population control and planning. The cities need more open spaces and planned development.
My thoughts exactly. Greatness.
Likewise, I hope Obama does NOT nominate John Kerry and reward the intransigent GOP with another seat Scott Brown can run for.
I hope President Obama picks someone who angers Congressional Republicans just as much, even if it is for different reasons.

It's always the expats that are far away that have no skin in the game that have all the answers that they would like to dictate. The "it is an impoverished" country so historical monuments/space programs/defense spending whatever line is pretty tired. Simply doing away with one or the other doesn't solve the problems. I am not sure that filling up the city with 22 yard long apartments does anything long term except increase the density of the city and make it even more unlivable. One only has to look at all the housing projects built in NY and other cities, that are now being torn down, to see how unsuccessful they were. There is a middle ground between "anglophile colonialist" and reactionary long distance know it all, and that is to preserve all aspects of Indian history. The colonial part is part of it. And it is the reason why people are commenting in English on this website.
No, except to say that try working harder, instead of blaming others.
Perhaps that is because the natives are writing like you?

For some unexplainable reason foreign students seem to have a better shot at admission in an ivy league university here  in US than the US born students. Is it a deliberate policy to co-opt the future " leaders of " a foreign state, at an early age ? Even when a foreign student is not of the right  calibre, he/she has more chances than somebody from here who work their behinds off to get into a prestigious school. To boot they also get almost 100 % financial aid. Can somebody explain this?

Lutyen's Delhi doesn't have to torn up; however, a lot can be done to help it meet 21st century needs and make Delhi more functional and operate more efficiently while maintaining its key historical and architectural elements.

Let us just look at it from an urban transportation perspective. Lutyen's Delhi has great access as it serves as the node for Metro system, has wide roads with ability to handle more traffic compared to other roads, and a reliable electric network.

Perhaps a good use of the land being currently used for all these governmental bunglows would be to build high rise buildings - they can be properly designed to be green and blend in with the correct architecture - to move the while collar jobs from the suburbs of Gurgoan and Noida to Lutyens Delhi - the center of the Delhi metropolitan area. It would cut the travel time for thousands, reduce unnecessary trips and help mitigate the air pollution problem. It is a sin to have a family of 2-8 persons living on 2-3 acre plots in the middle of the best accessible areas of the city for near rent free housing. They should all live in housing with a much smaller land print and closer to their constituents.

DCA
IIT GAO - Founding Member

Stanford admissions is certainly not like a game of Tetris. While I can predict with relative certainty which of my applicants will be accepted to Harvard or Yale, Stanford always seems a bit hit-or-miss. Am I the only one who feels this way?

Why? Because Bush took Clinton's surplus and blew it on two wars and a huge tax cut for the rich. He shut down regulation of the banks, who made a fortune lending to anyone warm enough to sign a mortgage, and then wrapped the mortgages in so many legal lies that they practically claimed they were backed by gold at Ft. Knox. Meanwhile, leverage ratios -- the fraction of borrowed money to real money -- at the banks rose to 30 to 1. As Bush was leaving this house of cards collapsed around him, taking down Lehman, Countrywide, Bear Sterns, Merrill Lynch, AIG, Fannie Mae, and Freddie Mac. As he exited stage right, Bush wished Obama well.

In panic, the economy fell 9% in the next few months, starting the Great Recession that still continues. The Recession killed the job market, which dramatically increased demand for food stamps and the number of people living in poverty.

That's why.

Um, federal salaries already are public.  We don't have any secrets.  We've been used as a Republican punching bag for years; for the last three, we haven't had so much as a cost of living adjustment.  Perhaps you should consider looking elsewhere if you think there's some secret government conspiracy to enrich government workers.

The highest numbers of people on food stamps are PRECISELY the result of the success of the safety net. People are hungry -- because Republicans failed to regulate the financial markets -- and food stamps are there to prevent people from actually starving. You know, like in sub-Saharan Africa, no-crops-because-of-draught STARVING.

Again, because it's worth repeating: the three primary causes of our current deficit are (a) Bush tax cuts, (b) Bush unfunded wars, and (c) Bush-caused recession (and unemployment) reducing tax revenue.

The deficit isn't about federal employees and their benefits; it's about the defense budget and the Bush tax cuts. Let's change both.

If the great "social safety net" of the past 50 years has been so successful then why the highest numbers of people on food stamps in history, and the highest numbers of those living in poverty. The left has given us a large and growing class of those who feel that the government can do it best. But the fact is they cannot. There is absolutely nothing wrong with increasing the tax rate on those earning above $200,000. per year. However, doing so will only raise enough additional revenue to run our government at current levels for about eight days. Publish the salaries of federal employees, along with the cost of their benefit packages, then tell me there is no room for reigning-in spending.

The Rice nomination was a test. Obama failed, he caved! That does not bode well now that that Republicans know he will eventually cave. What Obama needs to do is go to the public with this debate. That is why Boehner wanted private negotiations. You don't have to explain your intransigence to the public if they don't see it to begin with. Obama can clearly show the Republicans are not offering any solutions. Here is how you do it:

1. Write up a white paper explaining in some detail your proposal. Make it easy for the average person to understand. Maybe Professor Krugman or Bill Clinton can volunteer some editing on it, as they are the best of the best at explaining this sort of thing.

2. Hold a press conference waving the document, put it up on the web for all to read. Say you will wait for the Republican response, which also has to be posted on the web site. Suggest Republicans specify what loopholes they will close. The loopholes are all well known, suggest a few, like mortgage interest, capital gains differential, etc. that they could name.

3. Wait for Republicans to raise a huge hissy fit. Say fine, where is your proposal on which web site? When they finally get around to posting, it will be nothing, because they have nothing. Again, ask for specifics.

This forces Republicans to be the bad guys to what to cut your favorite deduction.

Will this happen? No, Obama will cave. But we can dream for a while.

To reject the Laffer Curve is to take the Democrat's position that tax revenues are a linear function of tax rates, i.e. that 150% percent income tax rates will deliver 3x the revenue of 50% income tax rates. History and common sense have repeatedly shown the Dems' position to be folly.
I agree!  Bring it on!

Let the fiscal cliff happen. I think the nation will survive. The net effect of more revenue is in the long run beneficial and we will could get back the higher tax rates on inheritance, upper level incomes, and the legal lootings engaged in by the Wall Street mafiosi.

It also means more taxes from those who will be stressed but most can ultimately afford to pay. It's a cost many of us are willing to assume.

This means that revenues will eventually be closer to expense and while that is delusional as a concept of prudence, it may open the door to spending on infrastructure that better prepares us for the effects of climate change, the end of the carbon burning era, and less waste in areas like defense with its absurd spending on useless technologies.

The Republicans are working themselves into irrelevance. A party committed to anti-science, money for its own sake, war and isolation as policy, with a cruel view of the poor, and led by the likes of Palin, Ryan, and Santorum, and funded by the likes of Adelman and paying serious attention to clowns like Trump, is not looking for solutions.

Eventually, we might have a Congress and a Supreme Court that could conquer the NRA.

I agree.  Entitlement has a negative connotation, but it's really an entitlement in the truest sense that I've paid this regressive tax for a lifetime and am therefore entitled to rely on it for my own retirement.

I love Bernie Sanders. He shows us how to be a great leader.
